Award.AwardTitle: SG: Genome-wide analysis of phylogenetic conflict in the wheat tribe, Triticeae
Award.AbstractNarration:
The wheat tribe, Triticeae, comprises about 350 grass species, including wheat, barley, and rye. Genetic exchange among species has played a major role in the group?s complicated evolutionary history, so a clear understanding of the relationships among species remains elusive. In species that exchange genetic material, the genomes can be mosaics derived from multiple sources, and as a result, evolutionary relationships inferred from genetic data can differ depending on which portion of the genome is used for the inference. Gene exchange has been convincingly implicated in the Triticeae, but the extent is still unknown. This research addresses the question by applying a genome-wide approach, sampling large numbers of short DNA sequences from throughout the entire genome from a broad sample of Triticeae species. The density of genome sampling, combined with the ability to determine the genomic location of the sampled sequences, will lead to a better assessment of the extent of genetic exchange, including which species are involved, and which regions of the genome are most affected.

The results of this work will be informative to Triticeae breeders who rely on the processes of hybridization and gene exchange as tools for crop improvement. The methods of data analysis developed in this project will be useful for studies of other groups of organisms that undergo gene exchange. The funding will support training for one graduate student, along with discussion groups and training for a selected group of undergraduates from Olive-Harvey College, a minority-serving two-year college in Chicago.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Context and Rationale. We often depict evolutionary relationships in the form of a tree, on which the branches represent evolutionary lineages that split (speciate) and diverge from one another over time. Analysis of DNA sequence data has become a primary means of determining evolutionary relationships. The amount of genetic data that we can generate and analyze has increased dramatically, and with that increase it has become ever more clear that branches on evolutionary trees do not merely split and diverge, but they might also later merge together. Such mergers among lineages are broadly referred to as hybridization, and they can lead to exchange of genetic material among formerly separate lineages. The research funded by this award was designed to clarify evolutionary relationships in the wheat tribe (Triticeae), an economically important group of grasses that includes wheat, barley, and rye. The wheat tribe is characterized by widespread past hybridization; this has long complicated efforts to develop an unambiguous picture of its evolutionary history.

Project and Results. This study applies DNA sequence information from over 1000 genes from the main nuclear genome, and from nearly complete sequences from the semi-autonomous chloroplast genome, to clarifying the relationships in the wheat tribe. We obtained a well-supported evolutionary tree from the chloroplast genome, and confirmed that the relationships on this tree are very distinct from those obtained from nuclear genes (or from any other source of data that we know of). This suggests a long history of hybridization, during which the chloroplast genome was passed among lineages multiple times. Relationships among nuclear genes showed fewer differences, but they are not in complete agreement. Some species (including the familiar barley and wheat) have reasonably stable relationships, while others are found in different places on different trees. Furthermore, certain regions of the nuclear genome show more conflict than others when compared to a tree of collected information. These results suggest that portions of the nuclear genome have been passed among certain species in the past, though none have been affected as dramatically as the chloroplast genome.

Conclusions. Previous studies of cultivated wheat and its closest relatives have revealed a history of extensive genetic exchange among the recent ancestors of this important crop species. In this study, our broader analyses of the entire tribe show that such processes are not limited to recent exchange among close relatives, but characterize the history of the entire tribe. 

Educational opportunities. The research provided training and support to one graduate student (now a post-doctoral fellow) and facilitated the completion of their dissertation; two undergraduates from our institution (one of whom is now enrolled in a veterinary medicine program); and two undergraduate interns from a minority-serving community college (both of whom later enrolled in our program and plan to apply for post-graduate studies).
